title: Subdomain Takeover (moderator.ubnt.com)
content:
Hello Team
This report is same as #179110
One of your subdomain http://moderator.ubnt.com is pointing towards
Code 104 Bytes
1216.58.203.243    moderator.ubnt.com
2216.58.203.243    ghs.google.com
3216.58.203.243    ghs.l.google.com
<image_0>
When I open it
it is showing
<image_1>
Impact :-
An attacker can claim this subdomain by requesting a process of registering this abandoned subdomain to his name.
And attacker can fully take over this subdomain and do whatever he wants. this can cause huge damage to the website's main domain as well as to the company.
I Recommend removing the Cname and DNS connecting to it.
You can read about this sort of attacks here : https://www.siteground.com/tutorials/googleapps/google_calendar.htm
To clarify your doughs I just added video POC
1ST Video Is about how I am able to claim it https://youtu.be/51Ku4cGbijE
2ND Video is proof when trying to claim it for the second time https://youtu.be/GJcWsHJj8aE
steps: Identify the subdomain (moderator.ubnt.com) pointing to a non-existent or abandoned service (ghs.google.com).
Verify the subdomain is vulnerable by checking DNS records (CNAME pointing to ghs.google.com) and observing the error page.
Claim the subdomain by registering it with the service provider (Google in this case).
Demonstrate the takeover by hosting malicious content or phishing pages on the subdomain.
vuln_description: The subdomain moderator.ubnt.com is vulnerable to subdomain takeover due to its CNAME record pointing to ghs.google.com, which is no longer in use. An attacker can claim this subdomain by registering it with Google, allowing them to host malicious content or phishing pages, potentially damaging the main domain's reputation and security.
reason: The vulnerability involves identifying a subdomain with a dangling CNAME record and understanding the process of claiming it with the service provider. While the steps are straightforward, the discovery requires knowledge of DNS records and subdomain takeover techniques.

authnz_metadata.reason: The subdomain takeover report involves DNS and CNAME configurations rather than authentication or authorization vulnerabilities within an application. The proposed methodologies focus on testing AuthN/AuthZ boundaries within an application by manipulating user sessions, actions, and resource IDs, which are not applicable to DNS misconfigurations.

injection_metadata.reasoning: The reported subdomain takeover vulnerability stems from DNS misconfiguration (CNAME pointing to an unclaimed Google Hosted Service), not from injectable parameters in HTTP requests/responses. The described methodology focuses on finding injection vulnerabilities by analyzing parameters in web requests and testing payloads in those parameters. Since this vulnerability exists at the DNS/domain configuration level rather than in web application input handling, the methodology would not detect it. The attack vector requires domain ownership validation bypass rather than parameter injection.
